content:
It's funny to find an O(N) algorithm for this puzzle.
But it's a pity that the test case can't be too long.

Nice introduction :)
I can solve  a limit of 10^5 chars in less than a second:
*deleted*

I don't see a point for k<=500, as there are only 26 lowercase characters.

It was quite late and I was too sleepy to edit the whole text and work on the story. I will be further fixing this one. Also I am looking for other ways of getting bigger test cases as currently, I am limited with 1000 chars per test case.

I would like to hear what you guys think, and if anyone has an idea of how to get bigger inputs (making the puzzle harder, as you can brute force it with this time limit), please do let me know.

As said, i'll be fixing it soon.
Also, you are not supposed to send your Code here, in comments, as everyone can see your solution now.

And finally, solving for 10^5 is quite easy, that's why I said i'll work on the limits, making it harder. 

P.S. Please delete your source code.

Yeah, that's exactly what I was looking for. O(N) exists and it's a cool solution, but unfortunately I can't put bigger test cases.

I tried reaching to CG about it and they said they are having a debate about the input size, so who knows, we might get it :D

Of course k affects the result. But not beyond 26 (when there are only 26 different characters in the alphabet, a substring can't have 500 different characters).

Except for the sorting of 26 entries (could be assumed as a large constant), I have a time complexity of O(n), while BruteForce has O(n^2).

I deleted the code.

Thanks for the feedback, as mentioned twice already, it was late and I just wanted to send it, I will be fixing it now.

Also, please delete your explanation of how to solve the puzzle, that's not the point of this.
